text_input:
This image is linked with the following caption provided by a user.
Caption: Isn‚Äôt it funny how we all¬†crave to be seen and heard, but¬†we are scared to death¬†to step¬†into the light to be truly seen and heard. We have our passionate, gritty stories to tell‚Ä¶ stories that our very humanity depend on‚Ä¶ but our voices shake and we are paralyzed with fear over what that kind of vulnerability might evoke when we commit to words, breath, and space. The shame is so intense and brutal that just as we are about to unmask ourselves we pull our hand away with what our brains can only discern as certain death. The hardest vulnerability I have had to suffer is to be imperfect to my children. This has been the hardest part‚Ä¶ where my ego and my heart intersect. It has taken me a long time, but I have free fallen into motherhood. I let it sweep me up in the wind and twirl me around. I let go of my grip and I loosened my sway to it, but it catches me off guard in so many ways. I should be invincible, unstoppable, fearless, and full of conviction. Instead I am broken and unsure and incapable and without answers. I battle the worst voices within me to prove my worthiness to motherhood every day. I have to wade through the sadness of my humanness and profess my love as the anecdote to my extreme lack. I hope that somehow in between all of these flaws that they will forgive me and grow through that, up through the mud and bloom and find the light. And I hope they will always stand firmly planted in it. #realtalk #honestmotherhood . . . .

text_input:

Caption: Another miraculous moment I am blessed to have: had a chance to photograph this Inle fisherman on sunset!
‚Ä¶
Many references I read said that Inle is truly best for its sunset‚Äîwhile Bagan is for its sunrise. A main reason that then pushed me told the boat driver to take me back to the lake‚Ä¶ while all tourists had already and were about went back to the port.

Though I have to spend some extra cash for that, I didn't regret, at all.

Giving myself my very own time, just me as the only tourist enjoying Inle's most beautiful sunset‚Äîright on the lake‚Äîand having this view to photograph‚Ä¶ again, how can I forget that?

text_input:
This image is linked with the following caption provided by a user.
Caption: TMI alert!!! ü§≠
So‚Ä¶.. some of you might remember that a couple months ago we learned that one of our kiddos developed an allergy to gluten. Well‚Ä¶ after further testing we recently learned that he‚Äôs also allergic to cow‚Äôs dairy AND PORK!!!!! üò±THE HORROR!üò´üò≠üò≠üò≠
.
But, as close families do, we‚Äôre in this together! That means, when we eat at home, as a family, we‚Äôre all sticking to the same diet. 
We don‚Äôt want him to feel alone in this food journey. (seriously, no pork? WTFüò≠)
.
Of course at events we‚Äôll cook what our clients want us to cook, and also continue some of the recipes we had planned for the blog. But at home, for our regular family meals, it will be different for awhile. .
Now, our doc advised him to go off these three foods for at least 6 months, and then reintroduce them in very small quantities, to see if symptoms come back. So this isn‚Äôt necessarily a food death sentence. But it is a big deal for right now (as at least cow‚Äôs dairy and pork are a HUGE part of our diet and lifestyle). .
.
That being said, we‚Äôre not giving up eating delicious, full flavored, foods anytime soon. We‚Äôre just learning to adapt. .
.
Like this steak. One of my favorite ways to cook a steak is to reverse sear it by smoking it at a low temp for about an hour and then finish it on a smokin‚Äô hot cast iron skillet with lots of butter and fresh herbs (like rosemary). Without the option of cow‚Äôs butter, we tested it out last night with goat‚Äôs milk butter. I was nervous, because goat‚Äôs butter has a very strong flavor. It‚Äôs very different from cow‚Äôs butter. .
.
But guess what? The flavor did not overpower the steak, at all! In fact it was downright delicious! Not as rich and creamy in texture as the cow‚Äôs, but it certainly did the job well!
.

Now off to do more exploring. .
.
ps, if you have any favorite dairy free substitutes I‚Äôd love to hear them! That‚Äôs been the hardest one for us so far. And pork. WHYYYYYYYYY?!?!?!?! üíî .
.
.
.
.

text_input:
This picture corresponds to the subsequent description given by a user.
Description: Growing up my mom used to have outdoor chores for my brothers and I. One of them was gardening. My mom used to have us pull the weeds, make the holes in the ground, plant the seeds, water the plants, and collect the fruits, vegetables, and seeds. She obviously helped and did the big woman jobs that we couldn't do like preparing the ground, using the big tools, etc. At first I hated it but over the years I have grown to love it and have a passion for it. I saw the passion that my mom has for her gardens. The love she poured out into her flower beds. The nurturing care for each plant. Her careful sketches of her yard and garden designs noting down each flower placement, each bush, vegetable plant, tree, fruit bushes, you name it. Every little detail that she puts in to her yard showed her entire love and passion for gardening. Our home stood out amongst the best in colors and curb appeal. Her love started in Puerto Rico with my abuela (grandmother) who taught her just about everything she needs to know about cultivating the best fruits, the moon phases and how it affects our gardens to help nurish it and bloom stronger. She carries that with her till this day and I am proud to say that I am carrying it as well all thanks to her. Now I have my daughters help plant seeds and water our plants and hope to pass it on to them as well. üå±‚òâüåôüå≥üåª What is something that you are passionate about that would love to pass down to your children? üíö
#gardening #greenthumb #aloe #plants #flowers #orchard #mother #daughter #familystories #childhood
In which area of work does the user specialize? Offer a concise explanation.
text_output: gardening or lifestyle. The user shares a personal story about their passion for gardening, inherited from their mother, and their intention to pass this on to their children, which aligns more with gardening or lifestyle rather than travel.

Statement: And that‚Äôs a wrap! This week has been busyyyyyyy üêùüêùüêùüêù with classes which is my favourite way to workout! I‚Äôve done 2 Spins, 1 stages Spin and 4 Body Pumps üí™üí™üí™üí™ I am really enjoying my classes at the moment as I am pushing myself even harder to get my weights up in pump and to increase my gears in spin.
.
‚Ä¢
 In Pump I am really happy with the gains I‚Äôve made in the squats, chest and biceps in particular, I‚Äôm increasing my back too but it‚Äôs just the clean and presses which stop me from going further as getting under the bar quick aggravates my tendinitis üò© which then means triceps suffers too. But the weights I am now using I am very happy with and I‚Äôm happy with how my teaching is going too which makes me so excited for my advanced instructor course next week! .
‚Ä¢
Last week I started going to stages spin at the gym I‚Äôm going to be teaching at soon so I could get used to their style and it‚Äôs definitely helped my other classes! With stages it‚Äôs on a big screen at the front of class so everyone can see how hard your working which makes you work harder as everyone will see if you‚Äôre slacking off! It‚Äôs made me realise how comfortable I‚Äôve become in my other spin classes as I‚Äôm not pushing myself so guess what? Now I‚Äôm pushing myself and upping those gears to challenge myself and actually have more of a proper workout instead of not really working out and focusing on my teaching so now it‚Äôs the best of both worlds! .
‚Ä¢
So here is my challenge to you - next time you‚Äôre in a class or working out in the gym, think are you actually challenging yourself? Can you go faster? Harder? Stronger? Better? Let me know if you do and how it went!! .
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
